dek: Kate Maxwell reports on the best cafes, restaurants, pubs, and markets in London's East End including St. John Bread & Wine, Callooh Callay, and Broadway Market.
hed: The Best Restaurants in London's East End

items.caption: **[Pizza East](http://www.pizzaeast.com/)**, on Shoreditch High Street, pleases current tastes, but in the cockney past, street food often came from the River Thames—including oysters and eels, served in pies or [jellied](/cities/london/my-five/london-meals).

items.title: 2. Story Deli
items.caption: The new contender for the pizza crown is nearby: At **[Story Deli](http://www.storydeli.com/)**, paper-thin dough is piled high with pancetta, caramelized onions, cheese, and lettuce (3 Redchurch St.; 79-1819-7352; pizzas from $23).

items.title:
3. Brawn

4.Young Turks
items.caption:
**[Brawn's](http://www.brawn.co/)** meaty French small plates include boudin noir, bone marrow, and gelatinous trotters. The wine list favors small organic producers (49 Columbia Rd.; 20-7729-5692; plates from $11).





Over the 2011–2012 winter, the **[Young Turks](http://youngturks.co/)** collective became the [buzz of London](/daily-traveler/2011/11/young-turks-take-over-ten-bells-In-london) when they served a set dinner for $61 at the Ten Bells pub (one of their dishes, raw beef and oysters, is pictured). To find out their next location, follow them on Twitter: [@youngturks​food](https://twitter.com/#!/youngturksfood)).

items.title: 5. St. John Bread & Wine
items.caption: Chef Fergus Henderson's **[St. John Bread & Wine](http://www.stjohnbreadandwine.com/)**, the marginally less formal sister restaurant of St. John in Clerkenwell, has a bakery, a wine shop, and a nose-to-tail menu (94 Commercial St.; 20-3301-8069; entrées from $16).
items.credit: Courtesy St. John Bread and Wine

items.title: 6. Rochelle Canteen
items.caption: Margot Henderson, wife of Fergus, runs **[Rochelle Canteen](http://www.arnoldandhenderson.com/)** in a Victorian school on Arnold Circus. Her lunch-only menu also embraces "the whole beast" (20-7729-5677; entrées from $19; open Mon.–Fri.).

items.title:
7. Leila's Shop

8. Beigel Bake

9. Book Club
items.caption: Calvert Avenue stalwart **Leila's Shop** is a grocery/café serving great coffee, brunch, and lunch (No. 15-17; 20-7729-9789). For a salt beef bagel to rival New York's, hit the 24-hour **Beigel Bake** (159 Brick Lane; 20-7729-0616). The start-up crowd drinks and dances at the **[Book Club](http://www.wearetbc.com/)** (pictured) (100-106 Leonard St.).

items.title: 10. Callooh Callay
items.caption: The start-up crowd then heads for cocktails to **[Callooh Callay](http://www.calloohcallaybar.com/)**, which takes its name from Lewis Carroll's "Jabberwocky" poem (65 Rivington St.).

items.title:
11. Golden Heart

12. Counter Café
items.caption: Spot not-so-Young British Artists at the **Golden Heart** pub in Spitalfields (110 Commercial St.) and up-and-comers at **[Counter Café](http://thecountercafe.co.uk/)** (pictured), on the canal in Hackney Wick, which looks onto the Olympic Stadium (7 Roach Rd.).

items.title:
13. Violet Cakes

14. Bistrotheque
items.caption: **[Violet Cakes](http://www.violetcakes.com/)**, also in Hackney, is a cute-as-a-button bakery with sublime cupcakes, brownies, and macaroons (47 Wilton Way). Just behind gallery-laden Vyner Street, cabaret/restaurant **[Bistrotheque](http://bistrotheque.com/)** (pictured) has a pared-down look and a modern European menu—don't miss the poached foie gras with Melba toast (23-27 Wadeson St.; 20-8983-7900; entrées from $22).
If you go looking for a market, be sure to check which days it appears—the **[Broadway flea market](http://www.broadwaymarket.co.uk/)** happens only on Saturdays.

items.title: 16. Viajante
items.caption: The Town Hall Hotel's Michelin-starred **[Viajante](http://viajante.co.uk/)** is East London's poshest, with tasting menus influenced by molecular gastronomy. The bar serves creative cocktails in tankards (tasting menus from $103).

items.title: Popular Galleries
items.caption:
